title: 109_hr4099
content: The Act may be cited as the "Homeland Security Volunteerism Enhancement Act of 2005". The Congress finds the need for citizen preparedness in response to acts of terrorism post-9/11. The Act authorizes the Secretary of Homeland Security to recruit and utilize volunteers for homeland security efforts. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 authorizes the establishment of the Citizen Corps to coordinate homeland security volunteer activities. The program will be part of the USA Freedom Corps and headed by the Director of the Office of State and Local Government Coordination and Preparedness. Additionally, the Secretary may recruit, train, and accept volunteers for the Citizen Corps, bypassing certain regulations. The Secretary shall establish a Border Corps under the Citizen Corps, administered by the Commissioner of the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection. Members of the Border Corps will be volunteers who assist the United States Border Patrol in surveillance duties. Members of the Border Corps assist the Border Patrol in surveillance, communications, transportation, and administrative support duties. They also help with line watch operations, signcutting operations, and traffic checkpoints to prevent illegal entry and smuggling. The Border Corps assists the Border Patrol in various operations including traffic checkpoints to detect illegal entry and smuggling. Volunteers are not considered federal employees except for specific purposes outlined in the law. The Border Corps assists the Border Patrol in operations like traffic checkpoints. Volunteers must be citizens or legal residents over 18 and pass a background check. The Secretary can set conduct standards for Border Corps members. The Secretary establishes procedures for background checks for Border Corps volunteers. A training and certification program is created for volunteers. Travel expenses are reimbursed according to regulations. Members can be disenrolled at any time. Border Patrol staffing is also addressed. Border Corps volunteers are not allowed to displace employees. The Secretary must increase the number of Border Patrol agents as per the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004. A clerical amendment is made to the table of contents. Authorization of appropriations for Citizen Corps and Border Corps under the Homeland Security Act of 2002 is specified. $50,000,000 is authorized for Citizen Corps and $20,000,000 for Border Corps for each fiscal year from 2007 to 2012.
